encodingDesc.p: The file data/letters/1870-9/1871/71-02-10a-final.doc was converted from Microsoft Word format into TEI using an XProc pipeline.

head.supplied: [Lastly, another communication has been received from that gentleman, ¶ The text follows on from the announcement of a previous letter from M; see M to the Sociedad Rural Argentina, 1 January 1871. ¶ ...

div.p: Letter not found. The text given here is from 'Semillas de Australia' [Australian seeds], Anales de la Sociedad Rural Argentina, 1871, vol. 5, p. 197. [Ultimamente se ha recibido otra communication de aquel caballero, fecha el 10 febrero ppdo. en la q' avisa haber embarcadoen aquel dia una coleccíon de semillas de árboles de rápido de Australia, en el buque «Loch Fay» dirijido al Agente General de Victoria, en Lóndres, D. Jorge Verdon, con encargo á la Sociedad Rural Argentina, deseando de enviarlo sea ensayado su cultivo en diferentes localidades de este país para poder mejor experimenter su resultado.

Segun la lista que acompaña, las semillas que envía son las siguienttes:
The list is given below the translation. These species are listed again, some with one or more of common name, location where they grow naturally, and their use, in 'Semillas de Australia' [Australian seeds], Anales de la Sociedad Rural Argentina , 1871, vol. 5, pp. 275-6. In a few cases the name errors noted here have been corrected, or given in a new incorrect reading. There is no indication of the source of the additional information, although it is possible that it was with the seeds.

p.seg: [Lastly, another communication has been received from that gentleman,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The text follows on from the announcement of a previous letter from M; see M to the Sociedad Rural Argentina, 1 January 1871.

p.seg: dated 10 February. in which he reports having shipped a collection of seeds of fast-growing trees from Australia on the ship "Loch Fay" directed to the Agent General of Victoria, in London, Mr George Verdon, with a request to send it to the Argentine Rural Society, wishing their culture to be tested in different localities of this country in order to better test the result.
According to the accompanying list, he sends the following seeds:]

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Wenet.
Typesetter's error for Willd. (=Willdenow)? The typesetter or editor clearly had difficulty with M's hand; where a misreading is the probable cause of the error, this explanation is suggested in the notes. In some cases, while such an error is likely, it is possible that M's text contained a misspelling, and a reading is suggested without further comment.

padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Acacia mollísima
Typesetter's error for A. mollissima? diurrens
The typesetter appears to have omitted Acacia before a misread decurrens

cell.p:
Cusuarina
Typesetter's error for Casuarina? Corrected in later list, see note 2 above, but leptoclada is given there as heptoclada.
leptoclada mig suberosa
Typesetters misalignment and misreading? Casuarina leptoclada was named by Miquel (=Miq); Casuarina suberosa was attributed to Miquel (perhaps abbreviated to 'M', but read as 'W'; see Miquel (1868), p 337) although previously named by Otto & Dietrich (1841), p. 155.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Eucaliptus
Eucalyptus; the spelling used here is frequent in Spanish, but corrected in the later list, see note 2 above. finitis
Typesetter's error for E. fissilis; corrected in later list, see note 2 above. This is a nominum nudum in Guilfoyle (1877), p. 25, where in his list of native woods he attributes it to M and notes that it is allied to E. obliqua.

Port.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: No plausible name for which this might be a typesetter's error has been found. The only Pittosporum species named by Banks listed in IPNI is P. crassifolium (accessed 23 November 2019) . The later list gives its locality as 'De Neuva Zelandia' [From New Zealand], see note 2 above.
